report_title: Cookie & Wafer Manufacturing in the US
executive_summary: Cookie and wafer manufacturers have endured significant challenges from pandemic-influenced supply chain disruptions, expanding input costs and heightened competition from imported brands. Although revenue drastically declined initially, signs of recovery emerged post-pandemic, and losses slowed but persisted. Sales continue to struggle as health-conscious consumers avoid high-sugar snacks like cookies, and a substantial and expanding portion of domestic demand is satisfied by imports. Revenue has been sinking at a CAGR of 2.0% over the past five years and is expected to slip 0.6% in 2024, reaching $6.1 billion.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: SUBSTANTIAL REVENUE LOSSES EASE BUT THE DOWNSLIDE CONTINUES
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Cookie and wafer production endured poor conditions during the pandemic, contending with supply chain disruptions, growing costs and greater competition from imported brands. Revenue fell drastically but showed signs of easing in the pandemic's wake. Despite improved operating and distribution conditions, cookie and wafer sales continue floundering. Many consumers are growing more health conscious, turning away from snacks with high sugar content, like cookies.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: CONSUMER SPENDING INFLATES BUT PURCHASING HABITS CHANGE
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Since cookies and wafers are considered discretionary foods, providing little necessary nutritional value, most consumers avoid purchasing them regularly during periods of low disposable income. However, in recent years, disposable income has expanded and consumer spending is climbing. Despite spending more, consumers are making different decisions on where to spend their money. Many contend with climbing necessary grocery costs, deterring cookie and wafer purchases when making household grocery trips.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Producers are Stiffled by Prohibitive Operational Costs
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: In recent years, cookie and wafer producers have contended with expanding input costs, particularly in the price of sugar and wheat, two key components in many production facilities. Attempting to cut costs, producers have minimized their workforces, reducing the average number of employees per facility. Many opted to retain and hire less skilled or knowledgeable workers. Regardless, wage costs climbed, as sales continued to shrink. The average cookie and wafer producer started the period with historically low profit, and rising production and wage costs have inhibited profit growth, keeping it extraordinarily slim and deterring new entrants.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A More Health Conscious Public Will Provide Long-Term Hurdles for Producers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Households have historically become increasingly health conscious as science advances and more information becomes widely available. In the coming years, consumers will become increasingly health conscious. Per capita wheat consumption is set to continue its downward trajectory as more consumers are diagnosed with related allergies or recommended wheat-free diets for different reasons. Unless cookie and wafer manufacturers begin relying on different base flours, the inclusion of wheat will weaken sales.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: A FALLING US DOLLAR COULD PROVIDE AN OPPORTUNITY TO GAIN BACK DOMESTIC MARKETS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Through 2029, the value of the US dollar is set to fall, making imported products relatively more costly for domestic markets. The development could provide a key opportunity for producers, as imports have ballooned to capture more than one-third of domestic demand. With a price-based competitive edge, domestic consumers can appeal to at-home markets and regain some of the lost domestic sales they once had. However, brand loyalty is often strong with imported foods, especially snack foods, since the difference in price can be negligible, so weakening imports hold on domestic demand will likely be minimal.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: COOKIE AND WAFER MAKERS WILL LIKELY SEEK TO REVITALIZE THEIR INDUSTRY THROUGH INNOVATION
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Manufacturers will continue to add more high-speed depositors to their plants, boosting cookie production. Meanwhile, artificial intelligence (AI) will be used to conduct better quality control with greater regularity, improving the manufacturing process. Many companies will invest substantially in research and development in an effort to cater to shifting consumer demands. Healthier ingredients will be a large source of investigation, but also ways to reduce reliance on traditional suppliers to improve operational costs.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures bakery goods with higher fat and moisture content, such as cookies and wafers. These products are then packaged and sold to downstream wholesalers and retailers. This industry excludes cracker and biscuit manufacturing.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Per capita disposable income
threats: Low Outlier Growth - Healthy eating index

key_trends: Imports serve as a significant substitute for domestic cookie and wafer products. When the dollar weakens, imported cookies and wafers become more competitive against domestic offerings, challenging local manufacturers to maintain their control of domestic demand.

Alternative snack options pose a strong competitive threat to cookies and wafers. Substitutes like chocolate, granola and potato chips garner widespread consumer appeal and easily replace cookies and wafers in diets, especially when preferences shift towards other flavors or textures.

Cookie and wafer manufacturers grapple with the dual pressures. Escalating ingredient costs and increasing competition from imports are compelling producers to streamline operations by reducing workforce, yet wages continue to rise, squeezing profit. Strategies for revitalization will likely include investing in advanced technology and reformulating products.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Large retailers like supermarkets, grocery stores and warehouse clubs account for over half of sales but have weakened as health concerns reduce cookie/wafer purchases.
Hotels, restaurants and other food service providers are capturing a growing portion of revenue as consumers are more willing to indulge in treats away from home.
Wholesalers remain important for reaching certain downstream channels, though large producers are increasingly handling distribution in-house.

products_and_services.product_description: Cookies remain the dominant product but weakening wheat consumption has hurt sales as many varieties contain wheat flour.
Wafers are gaining traction as a healthier alternative to cookies, with fewer sweeteners and additives appealing to health-conscious consumers.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Cookies and wafers are discretionary snacks, so demand is higher when disposable income levels are high and consumers can afford premium goods.
Cookies and wafers are viewed as unhealthy due to high fat and sugar content, so sales suffer when more consumers follow healthy eating guidelines.
Sugar is a key input for cookies and wafers, so fluctuations in sugar prices influence production costs and selling prices, affecting revenue.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Imports Balloon to Over One-Third of Domestic Demand
international_trade_points.trade_description: Imported cookie and wafer brands have gained prominence, capturing over one-third of US demand since 2019 as consumers prefer foreign varieties.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Canada and Mexico Dominate but European Brands Gaining Favor
international_trade_points.trade_description: Canada and Mexico remain the largest import sources due to proximity and trade deals, but European brands from Italy and Germany are gaining market share.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Exports Fluctuate but Grow as Share of Revenue
international_trade_points.trade_description: Export values have fluctuated but now account for a larger portion of total revenue as domestic sales weaken for cookie and wafer producers.

international_trade_points.trade_title: USMCA Provides Trade Benefits with Mexico and Canada
international_trade_points.trade_description: The USMCA trade deal reduced tariffs on many goods traded between the US, Mexico and Canada, benefiting the cookie and wafer industry's large export volumes to those countries.

business_locations.location_description: The West region contains major ingredients like wheat, corn and sugar, so many manufacturers locate there to be near key inputs.
The Mid-Atlantic contains wealthy metropolitan areas like New York, Philadelphia and Washington DC, enabling high demand for premium foods like cookies and wafers.
The Great Lakes region is a manufacturing hub with many suppliers of machinery for the cookie and wafer industry, attracting manufacturers to locate there.
The Southeast has the highest population in the US, boosting demand for cookies and wafers, though the industry presence is relatively lower than the population share.

regulations_points.regulation_description: This law requires that companies comply with limits on the emission of pollutants. These rules apply to cookie and wafer manufacturers because building new products can release chemicals that can pollute the air.

This act ensures that cookie and wafer manufacturers don't pollute bodies of water. Since making smart appliances can create waste, companies might pollute streams of water if there isn't government regulation.
This rule is enforced by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA). It ensures that manufacturers include specific information on their products, including ingredients and nutritional content.

OSHA is a federal agency that enforces safety and health legislation in the United States. The agency ensures that workers are trained properly when operating in an unsafe environment. They also require manufacturers to offer their employees generous workers' compensation when they're injured on the job.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Licensing requirements are fairly light for cookie and wafer manufacturers. Most states will ask potential entrants to provide proof of age, a social security number and basic demographic information to set up shop.
Initial costs are very high, including purchasing a plant, buying machinery, paying workers and doing research and development to make new products.
Branding is essential in this industry, as manufacturers produce similar products. Cookie and wafer makers also distinguish themselves by selling new products and offering low prices.
Workers are required for some vital functions, but the costs of setting up factories, machinery and making cookies present a much higher barrier to entry.

basis_points.basis_description: Imports serve as a significant substitute for domestic cookie and wafer products. When the dollar weakens, imported cookies and wafers become more competitive against domestic offerings, challenging local manufacturers to maintain their control of domestic demand.

Alternative snack options pose a strong competitive threat to cookies and wafers. Substitutes like chocolate, granola and potato chips garner widespread consumer appeal and easily replace cookies and wafers in diets, especially when preferences shift towards other flavors or textures.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Similar to most manufacturing industries, becoming a cookie and wafer maker is difficult, as it requires extensive investment into plants, machinery and workers. These costs create significant barriers to entry for potential entrants, discouraging individuals from setting up shop, and enabling big players to maintain a large share of the industry.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Recent acquisition activity benefits prominent players
concentration_points.concentration_description: Big cookie and wafer manufacturers have engaged in mergers and acquisitions recently to increase their branding scope and adapt to new snacking trends.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Costs are Substantial and Climbing, Hindering Profit
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Cookie and wafer manufacturers purchase an array of necessary inputs like wheat, sugar, cooking oil, butter, chocolate, starch and dairy products, along with packaging and branding materials. Total purchase costs are high for the average producer, accounting for nearly half of sales. Since 2019, the price of key inputs, including wheat and sugar, have soared, and despite recent dips in certain input prices, they remain abnormally high, resulting in climbing purchase costs for cookie and wafer producers.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Workers are required for some vital functions, but the costs of setting up factories, machinery and making cookies present a much higher barrier to entry.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Changing Consumer Sentiment Can Cause Fluctuations
volatility_points.volatility_description: Cookies and wafers are largely considered discretionary goods, and most consumers purchase them in small quantities or infrequently, particularly when money is tight. Individuals also avoid cookies and wafers when watching their diet, as many are high in unfavorable content like sugar and fat.

volatility_points.volatility_title: While Exports Account For A Small Share Of Revenue, Imports Can Dictate Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Exports account for a small but rising share of revenue, so changes in export values ultimately have little impact on overall industry revenue. However, imports have ballooned to account for more than one-third of domestic demand. These conditions prime cookie and wafer producers to experience volatility stemming from import performance.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: HIGH-SPEED DEPOSITING HAS INCREASED COOKIE PRODUCTION
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Many manufacturers have been adopting high-speed depositors, which are machines used to accurately place portions of cookie dough onto baking sheets in a very fast manner. The adoption of these machines has enabled manufacturers to make cookies in a quick and effective manner, boosting the potential of the industry.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE (AI) HAS MADE THE MANUFACTURING PROCESS MORE EFFICIENT
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: AI has been employed in some cookie and wafer factories, enabling manufacturers to use real-time monitoring. Real-time monitoring helps companies find problems in the production process in real-time, optimizing production efficiency, minimizing waste and maintaining a consistent level of product quality.

FAQs.question: How has your company been affected by rising imports?
FAQs.answer: During the current period, imports have increased substantially, adding competitive pressure for manufacturers. Many consumers may increasingly opt for imported products as opposed to domestically produced cookies and wafers. Imports are expected to account for 33.3% of domestic demand in 2023.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a range of products or brands?
FAQs.answer: The industry's leading companies are large consumer packaged goods conglomerates. These companies are able to limit risk from changing consumer preferences. Many brands are still fairly specialized, offering an array of cookies and wafers.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices in recent years? How do you contend with fluctuations in key input prices?
FAQs.answer: The industry's primary purchases include wheat and sugar, in addition to dairy, cocoa and other baking ingredients. Prices of wheat and sugar have soared during the current period.

FAQs.question: Has your company pursued any acquisitions in recent years?
FAQs.answer: Larger companies and companies seek to acquire smaller specialty brands to expand their product portfolio.

FAQs.question: What do you do to safeguard your company's proprietary information?
FAQs.answer: To adapt to changing consumer preferences, companies have increasingly invested in research and development to continue to hold market share by developing new products and improving existing ones. Some companies may patent recipes to protect information.

FAQs.question: Does your company automate any production processes?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers rely on equipment for mixing dough and baking cookies and wafers. Although some companies still rely on manual labor for other processes in the cookie production process, others have begun to automate the production line, reducing wage costs.

FAQs.question: Has your company contended with any increasing regulatory expenses recently? How did COVID-19 and related safety measures affect profit?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers have contended with little changes in regulatory expenses in recent years. Many have had to increase costs and safety measures during the pandemic. Some companies reduced their workforce in facilities at any given time, while others took on additional measures to promote social distancing and mask mandates.

FAQs.question: Does your company benefit from international tariffs imposed on imported goods?
FAQs.answer: Cookie and wafer manufacturers aren't affected by tariffs, despite substantial import competition.

FAQs.question: How has volatility in commodity prices and key inputs affected your company's profitability?
FAQs.answer: The industry relies on wheat, sugar and other ingredients to make wafers and cookies, so volatility in these key inputs can directly affect profitability, particularly for companies without favorable contracts with suppliers to mitigate fluctuations. Growth in wheat prices have put downward pressure on profit.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare to your leading competitors?
FAQs.answer: Profit is expected to comprise 1.7% of revenue in 2023.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to pass on price increases to consumers? How do you fare with volatile input costs?
FAQs.answer: Sugar and wheat are the two key ingredients in cookies and wafers. As purchase costs are the largest cost for manufacturers, some companies may be inclined to pass along these price increases to boost profit while others may be reluctant to maintain competitive pricing. Companies with solid brand loyalty may pass along price increases with more ease.

FAQs.question: How do you adapt to changing consumer preferences? Have you launched any new products in recent years?
FAQs.answer: As consumers have increasingly adopted grain- and gluten-free diets, companies have needed to continue to expand their product portfolio to cater to niche markets.

FAQs.question: How do you limit impacts of volatile input costs? Do you have secure contracts with suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Companies must ensure adequate contracts with suppliers to maintain the high quality of ingredients and reduce volatility. Purchasing ingredients at fixed prices can minimize input costs and assist with production planning.

FAQs.question: How has fluctuating wheat flour consumption affected your company's financial performance? Have you pursued grain- or gluten-free product lines?
FAQs.answer: As one of the main ingredients in most cookies and wafers is wheat or other starch, revenue can fluctuate with consumer preferences. Consumers have increasingly adopted gluten- or grain-free diets, reducing demand for cookies and wafers.

FAQs.question: How did your company fare during COVID-19? How have you performed with overall growth in disposable income?
FAQs.answer: Per capita disposable income soared during the pandemic because the government gave out lots of aid. When disposable income levels are low, consumers tend to cut back on discretionary foods, such as desserts, or opt for less expensive and private-label brands.

FAQs.question: How do you deal with consumers' increasing demand for healthy food? How have you adjusted operations to changing dietary trends?
FAQs.answer: As consumers become increasingly health conscious, they tend to cut back on sugary snacks, such as cookies. Some companies have continued to capture market share by introducing gluten-free or reduced-sugar products. The healthy eating index is expected to rise in 2023.
